summary: interferon-induced transmembrane protein (IFITM) genes are highly conserved between vertebrates. they block entry of several viruses into target cells [1,2,3,4]. amini-Bavil-Olyaee and colleagues suggested that this might be due to IFITM-dependent alteration of intracellular cholesterol transport. membrane association of IFITM proteins is facilitated by intramembrane domain 1 (IM1) [26], which is palmitoylated, and this modification is required for restriction of viruses [27,28,29]. mutation of residues was compatible with normal IFITM3 localization and IFITM3/IFITM3 interactions, indicating that F75 and F78 are important for antiviral activity. eCFP/eYFP fusion proteins were efficiently expressed in transfected 293T cells. expression levels were similar for all fusion proteins with exception of SxFP-Lyn, which showed reduced expression levels. both SxFP-NM and SxFP-Lyn showed plasma membrane staining with some intracellular staining. fusion protein SYFP-SCFP exhibited diffuse staining in the cytoplasm with strong accumulation in the nucleus. analysis of the proteins in the FACS-FRET assay revealed no signal upon coexpression of unmodified SCFP and SYFP while fusing both proteins resulted in a strong signal. coexpression of SCFP and SYFP harboring different membrane targeting domains resulted in FRET when combinations of neuromodulin and Lyn membrane targeting signals were tested. Western blot analysis of transfected 293T cells revealed that all fusion proteins were robustly expressed. expression of IFITM5-based fusion proteins was slightly reduced compared to that of the other IFITM proteins studied. similar results were obtained in cells engineered to stably express IFITM1-3 and the respective SCFP/SYFP fusion proteins. reduced availability of the acceptor (in this case SYFP-IFITM5) results in reduced FRET-efficiency [43]. all FRET signals were more robust than those observed for SCFP/SYFP artificially targeted to membranes. 293T cells were transiently transfected with the indicated plasmid combinations. controls are not shown but were similar to those shown in Figure 1D. results of a single experiment performed with triplicate samples are shown. these observations are in keeping with known differences in cellular localization of IFITM1 and IFITM3. the data suggest that subtle differences in membrane localization and/or interactions between IFITM proteins can be more readily visualized when low amounts of plasmids are transfected. the data indicate that IFITM3 is more likely to form homooligomers than heterooligomers with IFITM1. 293T cells were transfected with plasmids encoding the indicated IFITM3 fusion proteins. protein expression was analyzed by Western blot using anti-GFP and anti-IFITM3 antibodies. similar results were obtained in two separate experiments. the results of a representative experiment performed with triplicate samples indicate SD. the strong FRET signal observed upon coexpression of IFITM3-wt and mutant IFITM-FF raised the question whether the assay employed was sufficiently sensitive to detect potentially altered membrane localization of IFITM3 variants and/or altered protein–protein interactions.
